- **Claudia De La Cruz** (Peace and Freedom Party)
## McCloud Community Services District Board At-large
## California Proposition 2, Public Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for public school and community college facilities. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 3, Right to Marry and Repeal Proposition 8 Amendment (2024)
“Constitutional right to marriage. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 33, Prohibit State Limitations on Local Rent Control Initiative (2024)
“Expands local governments' authority to enact rent control on residential property. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 34, Require Certain Participants in Medi-Cal Rx Program to Spend 98% of Revenues on Patient Care Initiative (2024)
“Restricts spending by health care providers meeting specified criteria. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 35, Managed Care Organization Tax Authorization Initiative (2024)
“Provides permanent funding for Medi-Cal Health Care Services. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 36, Drug and Theft Crime Penalties and Treatment-Mandated Felonies Initiative (2024)
“Allows felony charges and increases sentences for certain drug and theft crimes. Initiative statute.[10]”
## California Proposition 4, Parks, Environment, Energy, and Water Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for safe drinking water, wildfire prevention, and protecting communities and natural lands from climate risks. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 5, Lower Supermajority Requirement to 55% for Local Bond Measures to Fund Housing and Public Infrastructure Amendment (2024)
“Allows local bonds for affordable housing and public infrastructure with 55% voter approval. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 6, Remove Involuntary Servitude as Punishment for Crime Amendment (2024)
“Eliminates constitutional provision allowing involuntary servitude for incarcerated persons. Legislative constitutional amendment.[5]”
## Siskiyou County, California, Measure W, Appointed Auditor-Controller Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE WShall the current voter elected position of County Auditor-Controller become a Siskiyou County Board of Supervisors' appointed position of Auditor-Controller with an effective date of January 4, 2027?YES_________ NO__________”
## Siskiyou Union High School District, California, Measure Z, School Improvements Bond Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE ZWith funds that cannot be taken by the State and spent elsewhere, shall Siskiyou Union High School District’s measure to replace leaky roofs; update classrooms for Career Technical Education programs; and renovate Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEAM) facilities at Happy Camp High, McCloud High, Mount Shasta High and Weed High be adopted, authorizing $22 million of bonds with legal rates, audits, average levies below $29 per $100,000 of assessed valuation (raising $1.3 million annually) while outstanding, citizen oversight, and full public disclosure of spending?Bonds - Yes Bonds– No”
## South Yreka Fire Protection District, California, Measure T, Spending Limit Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE TShall the South Yreka Fire Protection District be allowed to increase the spending limit pursuant to Article 13B of the California Constitution to an amount not to exceed Ninety Thousand Dollars ($90,000) per year for a period from the last election to set a spending limit for the period not to exceed the next four years?YES_________ NO__________”
*This report provides an AI-assisted analysis of ballot complexity. Please note that this is a supplementary analysis and not a substitute for official election information.*
**This ballot is more complex than 57 percent of U.S. Ballots.**

column1: - **Claudia De La Cruz** (Peace and Freedom Party)
## McCloud Community Services District Board At-large
## California Proposition 2, Public Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for public school and community college facilities. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 3, Right to Marry and Repeal Proposition 8 Amendment (2024)
“Constitutional right to marriage. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 33, Prohibit State Limitations on Local Rent Control Initiative (2024)
“Expands local governments' authority to enact rent control on residential property. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 34, Require Certain Participants in Medi-Cal Rx Program to Spend 98% of Revenues on Patient Care Initiative (2024)
“Restricts spending by health care providers meeting specified criteria. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 35, Managed Care Organization Tax Authorization Initiative (2024)
“Provides permanent funding for Medi-Cal Health Care Services. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 36, Drug and Theft Crime Penalties and Treatment-Mandated Felonies Initiative (2024)
“Allows felony charges and increases sentences for certain drug and theft crimes. Initiative statute.[10]”
## California Proposition 4, Parks, Environment, Energy, and Water Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for safe drinking water, wildfire prevention, and protecting communities and natural lands from climate risks. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 5, Lower Supermajority Requirement to 55% for Local Bond Measures to Fund Housing and Public Infrastructure Amendment (2024)
“Allows local bonds for affordable housing and public infrastructure with 55% voter approval. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 6, Remove Involuntary Servitude as Punishment for Crime Amendment (2024)
“Eliminates constitutional provision allowing involuntary servitude for incarcerated persons. Legislative constitutional amendment.[5]”
## Siskiyou County, California, Measure W, Appointed Auditor-Controller Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE WShall the current voter elected position of County Auditor-Controller become a Siskiyou County Board of Supervisors' appointed position of Auditor-Controller with an effective date of January 4, 2027?YES_________ NO__________”
## Siskiyou Union High School District, California, Measure Z, School Improvements Bond Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE ZWith funds that cannot be taken by the State and spent elsewhere, shall Siskiyou Union High School District’s measure to replace leaky roofs; update classrooms for Career Technical Education programs; and renovate Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEAM) facilities at Happy Camp High, McCloud High, Mount Shasta High and Weed High be adopted, authorizing $22 million of bonds with legal rates, audits, average levies below $29 per $100,000 of assessed valuation (raising $1.3 million annually) while outstanding, citizen oversight, and full public disclosure of spending?Bonds - Yes Bonds– No”
## South Yreka Fire Protection District, California, Measure T, Spending Limit Measure (November 2024)

“MEASURE TShall the South Yreka Fire Protection District be allowed to increase the spending limit pursuant to Article 13B of the California Constitution to an amount not to exceed Ninety Thousand Dollars ($90,000) per year for a period from the last election to set a spending limit for the period not to exceed the next four years?YES_________ NO__________”

California Constitution be increased over the appropriations limit established by said article for each of the four fiscal years 2024-2025 through 2027-2028 in the amount equal to the revenue received from the special tax for Fire Protection and Emergency Response services previously approved by the voters in November 2020?”', '“Authorizes bonds for public school and community college facilities. Legislative constitutional amendment.[5]”', ""“To maintain 9-1-1 response times/ prepare for natural disasters byrepairing deteriorating county roads/bridges;fixing potholes;maintaining evacuation routes;bus services;becoming eligible for Humboldt's fair share of state/federal roads funding,shall a measure enacting a one-cent sales tax, generating approximately $24,000,000 annually for general government purposes, until ended by voters, with citizens' oversight, annual audits, public disclosure, all funds used only for local services be adopted?”"", '“Shall the measure be adopted authorizing a new special tax for Kneeland Fire Protection District, replacing the current tax if approved, providing a dedicated source of local funding for the protection of lives and property, with rates charged per parcel by use: $100 vacant, $180 improved/single-family residential, $250 multifamily residential, and $300 commercial/industrial, allowing a contiguous parcel exemption, and up to 3% annual inflation adjustment, and generating approximately $58,000 annually, until repealed by the voters?”', '“To ensure and maintain fire protection services and emergency medical response shall the Peninsula Community Service District Ordinance No. 2024-5.1, establishing a special tax until June 30, 2031, and raising an estimated $33,000 annually, be adopted?”', ""“To repair and upgrade outdated facilities, classrooms, and labs used for job training and science/ technology education, deteriorating roofs, electrical wiring, and plumbing, and aging student housing; and acquire, construct, repair facilities, sites, equipment, shall Redwoods Community College District's measure be adopted authorizing $120,000,000 in bonds at legal rates, levying $25 per $100,000 of assessed valuation, ($8,400,000 annually) while bonds are outstanding, with audits, independent oversight, and no money for administrator salaries?”""]","# Ballot for Humboldt County, California

## Klamath-Trinity Joint Unified School District, Area 7

## Arcata Fire Protection District, California, Measure M, Appropriations Override Measure (November 2024)

“Shall the appropriations limit established for Arcata Fire Protection District pursuant to Article XIIIB of the California Constitution be increased over the appropriations limit established by said article for each of the four fiscal years 2024-2025 through 2027-2028 in the amount equal to the revenue received from the special tax for Fire Protection and Emergency Response services previously approved by the voters in November 2020?”
## California Proposition 2, Public Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for public school and community college facilities. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 3, Right to Marry and Repeal Proposition 8 Amendment (2024)
“Constitutional right to marriage. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 33, Prohibit State Limitations on Local Rent Control Initiative (2024)
“Expands local governments' authority to enact rent control on residential property. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 34, Require Certain Participants in Medi-Cal Rx Program to Spend 98% of Revenues on Patient Care Initiative (2024)
“Restricts spending by health care providers meeting specified criteria. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 35, Managed Care Organization Tax Authorization Initiative (2024)
“Provides permanent funding for Medi-Cal Health Care Services. Initiative statute.[7]”
## California Proposition 36, Drug and Theft Crime Penalties and Treatment-Mandated Felonies Initiative (2024)
“Allows felony charges and increases sentences for certain drug and theft crimes. Initiative statute.[10]”
## California Proposition 4, Parks, Environment, Energy, and Water Bond Measure (2024)
“Authorizes bonds for safe drinking water, wildfire prevention, and protecting communities and natural lands from climate risks. Legislative statute.[5]”
## California Proposition 5, Lower Supermajority Requirement to 55% for Local Bond Measures to Fund Housing and Public Infrastructure Amendment (2024)
“Allows local bonds for affordable housing and public infrastructure with 55% voter approval. Legislative constitutional amendment.[6]”
## California Proposition 6, Remove Involuntary Servitude as Punishment for Crime Amendment (2024)
“Eliminates constitutional provision allowing involuntary servitude for incarcerated persons. Legislative constitutional amendment.[5]”
## Humboldt County, California, Measure O, Road Infrastructure Improvement Sales Tax Measure (November 2024)

“To maintain 9-1-1 response times/ prepare for natural disasters byrepairing deteriorating county roads/bridges;fixing potholes;maintaining evacuation routes;bus services;becoming eligible for Humboldt's fair share of state/federal roads funding,shall a measure enacting a one-cent sales tax, generating approximately $24,000,000 annually for general government purposes, until ended by voters, with citizens' oversight, annual audits, public disclosure, all funds used only for local services be adopted?”
## Kneeland Fire Protection District, California, Measure D, Fire Safety Protection Parcel Measure (November 2024)

“Shall the measure be adopted authorizing a new special tax for Kneeland Fire Protection District, replacing the current tax if approved, providing a dedicated source of local funding for the protection of lives and property, with rates charged per parcel by use: $100 vacant, $180 improved/single-family residential, $250 multifamily residential, and $300 commercial/industrial, allowing a contiguous parcel exemption, and up to 3% annual inflation adjustment, and generating approximately $58,000 annually, until repealed by the voters?”
## Peninsula Community Services District, California, Measure E, Fire Protection Services Parcel Tax Measure (November 2024)

“To ensure and maintain fire protection services and emergency medical response shall the Peninsula Community Service District Ordinance No. 2024-5.1, establishing a special tax until June 30, 2031, and raising an estimated $33,000 annually, be adopted?”
## Redwoods Community College District, California, Measure I, School Facilities Improvement Bond Measure (November 2024)

“To repair and upgrade outdated facilities, classrooms, and labs used for job training and science/ technology education, deteriorating roofs, electrical wiring, and plumbing, and aging student housing; and acquire, construct, repair facilities, sites, equipment, shall Redwoods Community College District's measure be adopted authorizing $120,000,000 in bonds at legal rates, levying $25 per $100,000 of assessed valuation, ($8,400,000 annually) while bonds are outstanding, with audits, independent oversight, and no money for administrator salaries?”
*This report provides an AI-assisted analysis of ballot complexity. Please note that this is a supplementary analysis and not a substitute for official election information.*
**This ballot is more complex than 81 percent of U.S. Ballots.**
